lines.text: Isn't there anybody in this town that's not afraid of Craig Belden?
Sure! Graveyard's full of them!
Don't take no guts to kill a man when he's cuffed!

slow - but the white man's way. First you stand trial. That takes a fair amount of time, and you'll do a lot of sweating! Then they'll sentence ya. I never seen a man who didn't get sick to his stomach when he heard the kind of sentence you'll draw. After that you'll sit in a cell and wait, maybe for months, thinking how that rope will feel around your neck. Then they'll come around, some cold morning, just before sun-up. They'll tie your arms behind you. You'll start blubbering, kicking, yelling for help. But it won't do you any good. They'll drag you out in the yard, heave you up on that platform, fix that rope around your neck and leave you out there all alone with a big black hood over your eyes. You know the last sound you hear? Kind of a thump when they kick the trapdoor catch - and down you go. You'll hit the end of that rope like a sack of potatoes, all dead weight. It'll be white hot around your neck and your Adam's Apple will turn to mush. You'll fight for your breath, but you haven't got any breath. Your brain will begin to boil. You'll scream and holler! But nobody'll hear you. You'll hear it. But nobody else. Finally you're just swingin' there - all alone and dead.
You're leavin' on the next train. I own the sheriff! I own this town! I own every man in it! You're leavin' on the next train, Matt!
00. I'll be on it... but there'll be two men with me, and one of them'll have a cut on his cheek.

Far as I'm concerned, you can go out on the street and get yourself killed anytime you want to, but, you know something, 40 years from now the weeds'll grow just as pretty on my grave as they will on yours. Nobody'll even remember that I was yellow and you died like a fool. That's your long view, son. Always take the long view.
don't try to stop me!
It's customary for the sheriff to cooperate - furnish deputies...
We've got our own customaries, Mr. Morgan. Anyway, the sheriff ain't around.
When's he comin' back?
He ain't comin' back.

[realizing he's being stonewalled, he puts his hands on his hips and smiles ironically]
What are you? Deputy?
Don't matter much what you call me.
[he takes a badge out of his pocket and throws it on the desk]

[looking at the badge]
I'm callin' you yellow!
Oh, and if any of the girls try and tell you how wonderful you are, don't believe them. I know. I used to deal there.
[she gets up]
Just like Jimmy - stobborn as a mule!
Next time you see Jimmy, say hello. We seem to have a lotr in common.
Maybe more than you know. He's dead!

[indignantly]
You're breakin' the law!

[angrily]
I AM the law!
You're kinda lonesome, missy.
I haven't been lonesome since I was twelve years old.
The human race stinks. I'm practically an authority on that subject.
What about Petey? You ain't getting out of this alive. Now you know that. That boy is going to be an orphan. You thought about that?
You've already got me dead. How'd I die? The only way I could die today is for you to kill me and that's a problem... Your problem.
Suppose I could locate them for you?
I'd take them both back to Pawley. They'll stand trial for rape and murder.

[after an ambush fails and Craig misses him with a bucket]
I oughta kill you for that.
Why don't you? Why don't you kill me?
You saved my life. I paid you back. But from here on in, they're all free shots.

[trying to plead for his son]
How can we settle this, Matt?
The law's gotta settle it, Craig. Not us.
I saved your life once. You owe me that. You owe me one life.
I remember you saved my life. But he took a life! He killed a woman! Just for the fun of it! Just...
Taking my boy ain't gonna bring your wife back.
My wife or somebody else's makes no difference. I took an oath for this job. The oath says bring him in. That's what I'll do.
What do you want me to do? You want me to beg, Matt? Alright, Matt. I'll beg. He's all I got. Matt, maybe it was *my* fault. You know, it ain't easy to raise a boy without a mother, Matt.

[coldly]
Yeah. I know, Craig.

[after warning Morgan to stay out of Gun Hill]
You see, Marshall; I know who owns that saddle.

[solemnly]
So do I.
